bibl.title: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, March 2, 1925

div1.p: LePrince discusses conditions of mosquito breeding and an experimental chemical to control mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, March 2, 1925
div1.opener:
MR. W. C. JOHNSON, President,
Box 1035, Memphis, Tenn.
MRS. CHAS. DEAN, Secretary
Collierville, Tenn. Local 92.
EXECUTIVE BOARD
MRS. E. W. HALE,
Whitehaven, Tenn.
COL. W. J. BACON,
Memphis, Tenn.
MR. W. C. JOHNSON,
Memphis, Tenn.
DR. T. C. GRAVES,
Board of Health, Courthouse
DR. L. D. FRICKS, U. S. Public
Health Service,
Memphis, Tenn.
MRS. CHAS. DEAN,
Collierville, Tenn.
Shelby County
Anti-Malaria Association
Mar 2/25
Dear Dr Carter
div1.p:
Mr R W Geiss of Union County Mas. Extrem Commis
sion, Elizabeth N. J. recently wrote me

“In regard to the paper presented by Dr Rudolphs
at the recent Atlantic City meeting of the N. J. Mas. Ext
Ass.

Dr Rudolphs stated that in all pools in which
mosquito larvae were found, there were present various
varieties of protozoa and other forms of animal life and
where these organisms were not present, no wrigglers were
found. In clay pits through the central and
southern portion of New Jersey, no breeding was found
supposedly due to the absence of these tiny organisms.

The newspapers are in error in stating a chemical has
been found which will destroy these organisms forming the food
of the larvae. The matter is yet in the experimental stages
& Dr Rudolphs expects to continue work along this line & try to determine
what would be the best chemical for use under a wide
variety of conditions”-.
